Tests.Comment: Indefinite integral:

Test: ArcTan[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[3]]/Sqrt[3] + Log[1 + x]/3 - Log[1 - x + x^2]/6
ArcTan[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[3]]/Sqrt[3] + Log[1 + x]/3 - Log[1 - x + x^2]/6

Tests.Comment: Definite integral:
Use Esc\[ThinSpace]int\[ThinSpace]Esc to enter \[Integral] and Esc\[ThinSpace]dd\[ThinSpace]Esc to enter \[DifferentialD]:
Use Ctrl+_ to enter the lower limit, then Ctrl+% for the upper limit:
Multiple integral with x integration last:
Integrate over geometric regions, in this case performing a surface integral:
Enter the same integral using Ctrl+$ for the region and Esc\[ThinSpace]el\[ThinSpace]Esc for \[Element]:
Integrals that may not converge are by default returned as conditionals:
Compute an indefinite integral:
Verify the answer by differentiation:
Compute a definite integral over a finite interval:
Infinite interval:
Doubly infinite interval:
Integrate a function with a symbolic parameter:
Obtain an answer without conditions on the parameter a:
Multivariate integrals:
Integrals of piecewise and generalized functions:
Integrals over standard regions:

Test: Integrate[x^4*y^5 + z^10, Element[{x, y, z}, Tetrahedron[]]]

Tests.Comment: Integral over a region defined by inequalities:

Test: Integrate[Boole[x + 2*y + 3*z < 2 && -1 < x < y < z < 1], {x, -Infinity, Infinity}, {y, -Infinity, Infinity}, {z, -Infinity, Infinity}]

Tests.Comment: Plot the integration region:

Test: HoldComplete[RegionPlot3D[x + 2*y + 3*z < 2 && -1 < x < y < z < 1, {x, -1, 1}, {y, -1, 1}, {z, -1, 1}, Mesh -> None, PlotPoints -> 50]]

Integrals of vector- and tensor-valued functions:
Integral along a complex line:
Along a piecewise linear contour in the complex plane:
Along a circular contour in the complex plane:
Integral with bounds depending on the previous variables:
Plot the integrand over the integration region:

Test: HoldComplete[Plot3D[Sin[5*x*y] + 1, {x, -1, 1}, {y, -Sqrt[1 - x^2], Sqrt[1 - x^2]}, Filling -> 0, Mesh -> None]]

Tests.Comment: Invoke RefLink[NIntegrate,paclet:ref/NIntegrate] automatically if symbolic integration fails:
Rational functions can always be integrated in closed form:
Sometimes they involve sums of RefLink[Root,paclet:ref/Root] objects:
Similar integrals can lead to functions of different kinds:

Test: (1/5)*(2*Sqrt[x]*(1 + x)^(3/2)*Sqrt[2 + x] - (1/(Sqrt[1 + 1/x]*Sqrt[x]))*4*Sqrt[(1 + x)/(2 + x)]*(Sqrt[1 + 1/x]*(2 + x) + I*Sqrt[x]*Sqrt[(2 + x)/x]*EllipticE[I*ArcSinh[1/Sqrt[x]], 2]))
(2*Sqrt[x]*(1 + x)^(3/2)*Sqrt[2 + x] - (4*Sqrt[(1 + x)/(2 + x)]*(Sqrt[1 + x^(-1)]*(2 + x) + I*Sqrt[x]*Sqrt[(2 + x)/x]*EllipticE[I*ArcSinh[1/Sqrt[x]], 2]))/(Sqrt[1 + x^(-1)]*Sqrt[x]))/5
(2*Sqrt[x]*(1 + x)^(3/2)*Sqrt[2 + x] - (4*Sqrt[(1 + x)/(2 + x)]*(Sqrt[1 + x^(-1)]*(2 + x) + I*Sqrt[x]*Sqrt[(2 + x)/x]*EllipticE[I*ArcSinh[1/Sqrt[x]], 2]))/(Sqrt[1 + x^(-1)]*Sqrt[x]))/5

Tests.Comment: Many integrals can be done only in terms of special functions:

Test: (1/(4*E))*((-1 + E^2)*CosIntegral[I - Tan[x]] + (-1 + E^2)*CosIntegral[I + Tan[x]] + I*(1 + E^2)*(SinIntegral[I - Tan[x]] + SinIntegral[I + Tan[x]]))
((-1 + E^2)*CosIntegral[I - Tan[x]] + (-1 + E^2)*CosIntegral[I + Tan[x]] + I*(1 + E^2)*(SinIntegral[I - Tan[x]] + SinIntegral[I + Tan[x]]))/(4*E)
((-1 + E^2)*CosIntegral[I - Tan[x]] + (-1 + E^2)*CosIntegral[I + Tan[x]] + I*(1 + E^2)*(SinIntegral[I - Tan[x]] + SinIntegral[I + Tan[x]]))/(4*E)

Tests.Comment: Integrate special functions:
Integrate piecewise functions:

Test: Inequality[Piecewise[x]*x, LessEqual, -1 - 2/3 + x^3/3 - 1, Less, x, LessEqual, 1 - 4/3 + x*True]

Inequality[Piecewise[x^3/3]*x, LessEqual, 1*(1/3) - Sqrt[Pi/2]*FresnelS[Sqrt[2/Pi]] + Sqrt[Pi/2]*FresnelS[Sqrt[2/Pi]*x]*1, Less, x, LessEqual, 2*(1/6)*(2 - 3*Sqrt[2*Pi]*(FresnelS[Sqrt[2/Pi]] - FresnelS[2*Sqrt[2/Pi]]))*True]

Tests.Comment: Regions can be given as logical combinations of inequalities:

Test: Integrate[Boole[1 < x^2 - y^2 < 4 && x*y < 1 && x > 0 && y > 0], {x, -Infinity, Infinity}, {y, -Infinity, Infinity}]

Tests.Comment: Visualize 2D regions using RefLink[RegionPlot,paclet:ref/RegionPlot]:

Test: HoldComplete[RegionPlot[1 < x^2 - y^2 < 4 && x*y < 1 && x > 0 && y > 0, {x, 1, 5/2}, {y, 0, 1}]]

Tests.Comment: Regions can be in any dimension; in this case integrate over a cone:

Test: Integrate[(x^2 + y^2)*Boole[0 <= z <= 1 && x^2 + y^2 <= z^2], {x, -Infinity, Infinity}, {y, -Infinity, Infinity}, {z, -Infinity, Infinity}]

Test: Inequality[Piecewise[1]*a, LessEqual, 0*((2 - a)/2)*0, Less, a, LessEqual, 1*(1/(2*a))*True]

Tests.Comment: Infinite number of regions:
Integrals involving unknown functions are done when possible:
Symbolic integrals can be differentiated with respect to parameters:
The variable of integration need not be a single symbol:
Combination of indefinite and definite integration:
Integrand with a removable singularity:
With no RefLink[Assumptions,paclet:ref/Assumptions], conditions are generated:
With RefLink[Assumptions,paclet:ref/Assumptions], a result valid under the given assumptions is given:
Specify assumptions to evaluate a piecewise indefinite integral:

Test: Integrate[Abs[x + Abs[x]^2], x, Assumptions -> Element[x, Reals]]
Inequality[Piecewise[x^2]/2 + (x^3/3)*x, LessEqual, -(1/3) - x^2/2 - x^3/3 - 1, Less, x, LessEqual, 0*(1/3) + x^2/2 + (x^3/3)*True]

Tests.Comment: Generate a result without conditions that is valid only for some values of parameters:
The ordinary Riemann definite integral is divergent:
The Cauchy principal value integral is finite:
Area of a disk with radius r:

Test: Integrate[Boole[x^2 + y^2 < r^2], {x, -Infinity, Infinity}, {y, -Infinity, Infinity}, Assumptions -> r > 0]

Tests.Comment: Intersection of a disk intersected with a square region:

Test: Inequality[Piecewise[1]*a, GreaterEqual, 2*((a*Pi)/4)*0, Less, a, LessEqual, 1*(1/2)*(2*Sqrt[-1 + a] + a*ArcCsc[Sqrt[a]] - a*ArcTan[Sqrt[-1 + a]])*1, Less, a, Less, 2*0*True]

Tests.Comment: Find the volume of a four-dimensional unit sphere:
Mean and variance of the normal distribution:

Test: Integrate[x*PDF[NormalDistribution[μ, σ], x], {x, -Infinity, Infinity}, Assumptions -> σ > 0]
Integrate[(x - μ)^2*PDF[NormalDistribution[μ, σ], x], {x, -Infinity, Infinity}, Assumptions -> σ > 0]

Tests.Comment: Compare to the asymptotic result:
Construct Enneper's minimal surface using Weierstrassian integrals:

Test: HoldComplete[ParametricPlot3D[Re[{Integrate[1 - x^2, x], Integrate[I*(1 + x^2), x], Integrate[2*x, x]} /. {x -> r*E^(I*ϕ)}], {r, 0, 3}, {ϕ, 0, 2*Pi}, Boxed -> False, Axes -> False, PlotRange -> All, Mesh -> False]]

Tests.Comment: Evaluate integrals numerically using RefLink[N,paclet:ref/N]:
Assumptions about variables can yield different forms:
Solve a simple differential equation:
RefLink[Derivative,paclet:ref/Derivative] with a negative integer order does integrals:
Laplace transform of an integral:
RefLink[ArcLength,paclet:ref/ArcLength] is the integral of 1 over a one-dimensional region:
RefLink[Area,paclet:ref/Area] is the integral of 1 over a two-dimensional region:
RefLink[Volume,paclet:ref/Volume] is the integral of 1 over a three-dimensional region:
Many simple integrals cannot be evaluated in terms of standard mathematical functions:
Simple-looking integrals can give complicated results:

Test: (1/8)*(2*Cos[(-1 + x)*x] - 2*Cos[x*(1 + x)] + Sqrt[2*Pi]*((-Cos[1/4])*FresnelS[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]] + FresnelC[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]*Sin[1/4]) + Sqrt[2*Pi]*((-Cos[1/4])*FresnelS[(1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]] + FresnelC[(1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]*Sin[1/4]))

(2*Cos[(-1 + x)*x] - 2*Cos[x*(1 + x)] + Sqrt[2*Pi]*(-(Cos[1/4]*FresnelS[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]) + FresnelC[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]*Sin[1/4]) + Sqrt[2*Pi]*(-(Cos[1/4]*FresnelS[(1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]) + FresnelC[(1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]*Sin[1/4]))/8

(2*Cos[(-1 + x)*x] - 2*Cos[x*(1 + x)] + Sqrt[2*Pi]*(-(Cos[1/4]*FresnelS[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]) + FresnelC[(-1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]*Sin[1/4]) + Sqrt[2*Pi]*(-(Cos[1/4]*FresnelS[(1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]) + FresnelC[(1 + 2*x)/Sqrt[2*Pi]]*Sin[1/4]))/8

Tests.Comment: The derivative of an integral may not come out in the same form as the original function:
Different forms of the same integrand can give integrals that differ by constants of integration:
Results for integrals can depend on the way parameters appear in an integrand:
The indefinite integral of a continuous function can be discontinuous:
Parameters like n are assumed to be generic inside indefinite integrals:
In definite integration, conditions are generated:
The integration variable cannot itself be a mathematical function:
When part of a sum cannot be integrated explicitly, the whole sum will stay unintegrated:
Substituting limits into an indefinite integral may not give the correct result for a definite integral:
The presence of a discontinuity in the expression for the indefinite integral leads to the anomaly:
Expanding RefLink[RootSum,paclet:ref/RootSum] objects from integrals may give large results:
A definite integral may have a closed form only over an infinite interval:
With too many components in a piecewise integral, RefLink[$MaxPiecewiseCases,paclet:ref/$MaxPiecewiseCases] may have to be increased:
